properties.name: Catenary Curve Wayside
properties.notes:
Catenary Curve Wayside
https://www.nps.gov/places/catenary-curve-wayside.htm

This wayside exhibit discusses the importance of the catenary curve in the design of the Gateway Arch and the curves echoed in the landscape design. It also includes a tactile map the groups and a tactible exhibit of the shape of the Gateway Arch and a catenary curve.

properties.name: Directly below the Gateway Arch
properties.notes:
Directly below the Gateway Arch
https://www.nps.gov/places/directly-below-the-gateway-arch.htm

Walk under the Gateway Arch and look up! The lush green lawn offers a great place for sitting or lying and taking a look upwards at the soaring curve of the Arch. Did you know that the Arch is 630 feet high and the two legs are also 630 feet apart? Move a bit to one side and look up and spot the windows of the observation platform.

properties.name: Dred and Harriet Scott Statue
properties.notes:
Dred and Harriet Scott Statue
https://www.nps.gov/places/dred-and-harriet-scott-statue.htm

Dedicated in 2012 by the Dred Scott Heritage Foundation, the National Park Service and sculptor Harry Weber, this statue of Dred and Harriet Scott honors their fight for their family's freedom. Their fight began in 1846 here at the Old Courthouse when Dred and Harriet began their long legal battle for their rights. Their case began here, but over the course of eleven years it made its way to the Supreme Court where the final verdict helped push the country to civil war. The Scott family didn’t find the freedom they sought through the legal challenge, but their courage and determination in filling this case helped bring about freedom from enslavement for all Americans.

properties.name: Eads Bridge
properties.notes:
Eads Bridge https://www.nps.gov/places/eads-bridge.htm

"It is indeed a structure of perfection and beauty unsurpassable, and I never tire of it," Walt Whitman, 1882

The Eads bridge was the first bridge across the Mississippi at St. Louis. It was a major engineering feat, the largest bridge built at that time and the very first steel bridge. Completed in 1874, it is the oldest bridge standing on the Mississippi River. It was designed and built by James Buchanan Eads, an engineer famous for his ironclad gunboats built for the Union in the Civil War. Learn more about the Eads Bridge at the musuem under the Gateway Arch.

properties.name: Flagpole
properties.notes:
Flagpole
https://www.nps.gov/places/flagpole.htm

The flagpole in Luther Ely Smith Square is a great place to start your walking tour of the Gateway Arch grounds. This central spot right along Fourth Street is a good meeting place to get your group together to start your visit. It is also a good spot to get your photo with the Gateway Arch or Old Courthouse.

properties.name: Flood of 1993 Marker
properties.notes:
Flood of 1993 Marker https://www.nps.gov/places/flood-of-1993-marker.htm This plaque marks the high water point for the Great Flood of 1993. On August 1, 1993 the Mississippi River reached 49.58 feet, the highest water level ever reported in the City of St. Louis. The flood affected many Midwestern states and caused 50 deaths and billions of dollars in damages. Stand on the Grand Staircase and try to imagine the water reaching the bottom of this plaque and the power of all that water. Can you or someone in your group remember the flood? How did it affect your family and friends? Do you think the river will ever reach this high again?  

This place is not accessible if you are unable to use stairs. You can see the location of the plaque from the top of the Grand Staircase. If you would like to descend to street level without using stairs, there are ramps on either side of the stairs.

properties.name: Gateway Arch Monument
properties.notes:
Gateway Arch Monument https://www.nps.gov/places/gateway-arch-monument.htm

"Neither an obelisk nor a rectangular box nor a dome seemed right on this site or for this purpose. But here, at the edge of the Mississippi River, a great arch did seem right." -Eero Saarinen

As the nation's tallest monument, the Gateway Arch has welcomed visitors for more than fifty years with its iconic, awe-inspiring shape. The vision of renowned architect Eero Saarinen, the Gateway Arch commemorates Thomas Jefferson's vision and St. Louis' role in the westward expansion of the United States.

Please see the information about the Gateway Arch Visitor Center for hours to visit the top and the museum, film, shop and cafe.

properties.name: North Pond
properties.notes:
North Pond
https://www.nps.gov/places/north-pond.htm

The curved lines of the ponds echo the curves of the Gateway Arch and add a beautiful feature to the grounds. The ponds are popular with ducks and geese and in the spring you may see them about with their young. Please respect the wildlife and keep your distance. Renovations to the grounds during the CityArchRiver project brought this accessible walk close to the pond.

properties.name: Old Courthouse
properties.notes:
Old Courthouse https://www.nps.gov/places/old-courthouse.htm The Old Courthouse was the site of the first two trials of the pivotal Dred Scott case in 1847 and 1850. It was also where Virginia Minor's case for a woman's right to vote came to trial in the 1870s. An important building in the history of St. Louis and the history of Civil Rights, the Old Courthouse is currently closed to the public. 

St. Louis' Old Courthouse is listed in the National Park Service's National Underground Railroad Network To Freedom. The Network to Freedom recognizes sites, programs and facilities with verifiable associations to the Underground Railroad. The phenomenon popularly known as the Underground Railroad has been broadly defined by the National Park Service as the "historic resistance to enslavement through escape and flight." The Old Courthouse is linked with the story of the Underground Railroad, and with that of slavery, as a property associated with legal challenges to slavery. It was a public forum as well as a courthouse. Enslaved people were auctioned from its steps in estate settlements, while one man's suit for freedom helped plunge the country into Civil War. The Old Courthouse was the site of over 300 suits for freedom, but one gained notoriety. In 1847, Dred Scott, with his wife Harriet, sued for, and were granted, their freedom. After many appeals, the case was decided upon by the Supreme Court. The decision stated that slaves were property, and as such, had no right to sue. The Dred Scott Decision hastened the start of the Civil War.

properties.name: South leg of the Gateway Arch
properties.notes:
South leg of the Gateway Arch https://www.nps.gov/places/south-leg-of-the-gateway-arch.htm The south leg of the Gateway Arch. Go ahead and touch it! Feel the smootness of the stainless steel and find the welds between the sections. The sections were constructed as triangles, then shipped to St. Louis where the triangular pieces were welded together. The triangular pieces become smaller and smaller as the leg rises into the air. Look up as the leg curves away and notice how the view changes as you move around the side to another part of the triangle. 

Please respect the historic fabic of the Gateway Arch. Touch it! Take a selfie! But leave no mark!

properties.name: The Captains' Return
properties.notes:
The Captains' Return https://www.nps.gov/places/the-captains-return.htm Commissioned by the Greater St. Louis Community Foundation to mark the bicentennial of the end of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, this 22 foot tall bronze statue shows the return of William Clark and Meriwether Lewis to St. Louis in 1806.

After its initial placement in 2006, flooding of the Mississippi River often led to the sight of the partially submerged statue with Clark waving his hat as in distress. In 2014, the statue was removed and restored to fix damage from the floods. In 2016, the statue was returned to the riverfront to a location slightly south and about 17 feet higher than before.  

The sculptor, Harry Weber's work is a familiar sight for St. Louisians with thirty-one works in the city, including the statues of Dred and Harriet Scott at the Old Courthouse, the Plaza of Champions at Busch Stadium and Malcom Martin at Malcom W. Martin Memorial Park across the Mississippi River.

properties.name: The Riverfront
properties.notes:
The Riverfront
https://www.nps.gov/places/the-riverfront.htm

Once the bustling heart of the city, the St. Louis riverfront on the Mississippi river is still a great place to take in the views and watch the river traffic. The riverboats you see to the south offer tours, tickets available in the Gateway Arch Visitor Center.
